Rock The Boat.

Friends:

This is You Love To See It, a weekly feature reviewing good news, progress, and action steps that’s one of the many features available only to Lever supporting subscribers. See a preview below and click here to upgrade for full access.

Rock The Boat.

children.text: Good things are happening! The U.S. is finally taking action to phase out super-pollutants, New York becomes the next state to phase out gas-powered vehicles, and California is rolling out new policies to transition away from natural gas in homes. Also, a referendum in Cuba has redefined rights for families, while farmworkers have just won historic labor protections.
All this and much more in this week’s edition of
— designed to cut greenhouse gas emissions by eliminating the use of hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs).
HFCs are chemicals that leak from cooling appliances like refrigerators and air conditioners. HFCS can be thousands of times

than carbon dioxide in terms of heating the planet. Cutting their use could prevent half a degree Celsius of global warming by the end of the century, a vital step when every tenth of a degree matters.
by countries participating in the Montreal Protocol in 2016, but President Trump never sent the amendment to the Senate. However, in December 2020, Congress

the American Innovation and Manufacturing (AIM) Act, which empowered the Environmental Protection Agency to phase out 85 percent of HFCs over 15 years. Now that target will be increased to 100 percent of these super-pollutants.
New York will ban the sale of all gas-powered vehicles by 2035, state Gov. Kathy Hochul (D)
Thursday. The move makes the Empire State the second state to mandate zero-emission vehicles, after California

To reach its goal, New York will require 35 percent of new car sales to be zero emission vehicles by 2026, and 68 percent zero emission by 2030. All new school buses purchased by the state will also have to be zero emission starting in 2027.
With California and New York boasting
two of the three largest state economies
in the country, these mandates will likely have a major impact on the car and truck industries. Together, the two states account for

“We had to wait for California to take a step because there’s some federal requirements that California had to go first — that’s the only time we’re letting them go first,” said Hochul, after arriving at the press conference in a zero-emission Chevy Bolt.

to become the first state in the country to ban the sale of gas-powered heating and hot water systems by 2030. Indoor fossil fuel use accounts for 12 percent of the country’s fossil fuel emissions. According to decarbonization researcher Denise Grab, “[in California] gas appliances emit four times more emissions than all of the state’s power plants put together, and nearly two-thirds of the emissions of all light-duty cars.”
will join the increasing number of California
facilitating a transition to climate-friendly building codes and appliances like
, which deliver more energy-efficient means of heating and cooling homes.
The unfolding transition will have numerous benefits for health and living costs, especially in
with lower incomes. Regulators in the

are projecting serious health improvements thanks to improved air quality from zero-emission heating. Moreover, electric heat pumps can regulate temperatures more efficiently than air conditioners or gas-powered appliances, lowering long-term energy costs .
Cuba Adopts A Progressive Families Code
This week, Cuba voted to adopt a
that guarantees the right of all people to form a family without discrimination.
Redefining how people can come together to form a family unit, the

, “Different family structures, based on a relationship of affection, are created among relatives, whatever the nature of the relationship, and between spouses or in common-law unions.” Under the act, people perform “family and societal duties on the basis of love, affection, consideration, solidarity, fraternity, co-participation, protection, responsibility, and mutual respect.”
The new Families Code was won by a tremendous democratic process that involved 75 percent of Cuba’s electorate. According to
, 20 drafts of the law were shaped by nearly 80,000 neighborhood meetings and 500,000 public proposals before 66 percent of voters

children.text: “The family code is the result of a collective endeavor,” Yamila Gonzalez of the Families Code Drafting Committee

. “All of those perspectives have resulted in a code that responds to the needs of Cuban families... At a time when we are witnessing the rollback of fundamental rights for women in the LGBTQ+ community, Cuba is guaranteeing all rights for all people at the family level.”
335 miles to the California state capital, the
(UFW) and their supporters pushed Democratic Gov. Gavin Newsom to sign the Voting Choice Act, a
that will allow workers to vote for unionization free from intimidation.
“This is an incredible victory. Starting next year, farm workers can participate in elections free from intimidation and deportation. Sí, se puede,” Teresa Romero, president of the UFW, said in a

of supporters in an effort that has now won vital protections from large agricultural associations and wealthy ranchers. Decades ago, labor and civil rights activists Dolores Huerta and Cesar Chavez led a similar march on the capital known as the pilgrimage, or the peregrinación. For many leaders of this summer’s march, the Voting Choice Act represents a step toward
and transforming the country’s commitment to the rights of farmworkers.

that keeps this world. I am

And here’s a special shout-out to our new Lever Leaders!
We recently launched a new higher-level subscription tier, with special exclusive benefits, for those who wish to support
beyond their current subscription level. Each week, we’ll highlight a handful of folks who’ve taken that step, and the reason they’ve done so. Here’s the first batch!
Want to become a Lever Leader?

. I am so happy to support true reporting and not mainstream media that is often influenced by billionaires.”

• Terri Monley: “I’m tired of watching the needle;
is the force to change it.”

• Stephen Puckett: “Lever is a strong voice firmly on the side of the working class.”

• Mark Proulx: “True investigative journalism must be supported.”
• Tammye Erb: “I believe in old-fashioned, honest news reporting and follow-the-money investigations and
lives up to its word “Rocking the Boat!”
While we highlight these people for their support this week, please know that we are thankful for each and every one of our supporters and readers. We could not do this work without you.
